newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan pro-China march draws scant following.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan pro-China march draws scant following.

text.p: On Saturday, 70,000 Taiwanese braved downpours to stage a rally asserting their island's independence from China prior to Beijing's reabsorption of Hong Kong.
On Sunday, supporters of Taiwan-China reunification held a rally intending to counterbalance Saturday's throng.

In a scant show contrasting with the fervour and sheer size of Saturday's anti-Beijing march, a drum-beating Chinese nationalist group took to the streets of Taipei to celebrate Hong Kong's July 1 handover to Beijing sovereignty.

Rebuffing the call by Saturday's protesters to prevent Taiwan from being gobbled up by China, Sunday's demonstrators hailed Hong Kong's impending handover and urged eventual reunification for China and Taiwan.

"Hong Kong's handover is something that all Chinese people should celebrate," Lee Chih-jen, organiser of Taiwan's Chinese Nation United Front which staged the march, said to a scattering of supporters.
"We are here to counterbalance the rally from Saturday, because otherwise the international world would believe that all the people in Taiwan support Taiwan independence," Lee said.
While Saturday's march included prominent members of opposition parties and a U.S. ex-congressman, Sunday's march was shunned even by leaders of Taiwan's largest pro-unification party, the New Party.

Whatever their stand on independence, Taiwan political groups universally reject what Beijing regards as a generous offer -- reunion under the "one country, two systems" model of local autonomy that underlies Hong Kong's handback.
Beijing, which has seen Nationalist-ruled Taiwan as a rebel province since a 1949 civil war split, vows to attack if Taipei stops advocating reunion and pursues independence.
Sunday's protesters branded independence supporters as "rejects of the Chinese people" who jeopardised Taiwan's prosperity and peace.
"The independence people are risking peace across the Taiwan strait in order to get attention," a protester said.

Taiwan's ruling Nationalist Party says it wants to unite with China, but only after Beijing's Communist Party agrees to adopt political reforms like those that have transformed Taiwan from an iron-fisted autocracy into a lively democracy.
